titleInfo.title: "Protect Our Daughters"
titleInfo.subTitle: How American Cable News Media Frame the Controversy of Young Gender Minorities in Sport

mods:mods.abstract: Since 2019, more than 30 states have proposed over 100 pieces of legislation seeking to ban or heavily restrict young transgender and gender minority athletes from participating in sports. Fully aware of the developmental, physical, and mental health benefits that sport can bring young people, state legislators have passed many of these bills. My thesis includes uses of Bem's (1981) gender schema theory (GST) to inform analysis of how stereotypes and discrimination against transgender people and gender minorities manifest from sex-typed associations and rigid gender schemas. As many Americans still don't personally know a transgender person (Minkin & Brown, 2021), we often turn to news media to stay informed. I use textual analysis to critically analyze how cable news media frame young gender minority athletes and the controversy of gender minorities participating in organized sport. Content-specific frames are developed for each of the three major cable news outlets (Cable News Network, Fox News Channel, and MSNBC) that characterize coverage of the controversy in transcripts between January 1, 2019, and October 16, 2021. Overarching frames were also developed that describe the strategies of all three cable news networks. Additionally, coverage was analyzed for how framing or representation may change based on the intersectional identities of the main athletes discussed in coverage during the time frame. Trends present over the designated time frame were also noted, amalgamating to a nuanced evaluation of how the inclusion of young transgender and other young gender minority athletes in sports is being framed by the three major cable news networks. Although there were differences between networks, overall, I found that there were overarching frames employed by all three outlets explored in this study: (1) there are only two sides to the issue at hand; (2) trans athlete participation is used as a political ploy by the "other side;" and (3) the beliefs about the issue on the "other side" reveal absurdity in the issue itself and the political party. These frames essentially oversimplify the issue by presenting it as a two-sided controversy—typically only reporting dominant arguments or beliefs in the form of Republican views versus Democratic views or right versus left—instead of an acknowledgement of the complexity and nuance of the conversation around the inclusion of gender minorities in sport.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
cable news, critical feminism, framing, gender minority, gender schema theory, transgender
Jennifer M. Proffitt, Professor Directing Thesis; Arthur A. Raney, Committee Member; Donna M. Nudd, Committee Member.
